title: European Soccer Wages
text: This model predicts a teams final season standing given its payroll rank within the league.

title: Overview
text:
Context
With the global commercialization of soccer, clubs have been significantly spending more on their squads. Takeovers from American investors and controversy concerning foreign investment has sparked topics about teams’ sources of wealth. Across many sports, there have been discussions about the implementation of salary caps.







Summary
The data was collected from fbref; since payrolls and standings were stored in different locations and separated by years, the data was compiled into a single excel file. Data includes the top five European leagues from mainly the 2013 to 2022 seasons. I estimated a Bayesian linear model with standing as the dependent variable and payroll rank as the independent variable.

title: Sources
text:
Data
All data was compiled using the fbref soccer database. Fbref description is an extensive soccer database, and it is part of the bigger sports data collection by Sports Reference. The website is well-suited to observe transfers and historical results across many leagues and years.


Process
Since data was broken up by season and year with standing separated from annual wages, I had to mannualy create an excel file to consolidate the data. This took a few hours of copy and pasting, but made the analysis part much easier. In total, there are 1052 data points in the final file.



Screen Shot of FBREF Salaries page





Screen Shot of Top5Leagues_Payroll.xlsx

title: About
text:
About This Project
With the help of David Kane’s Free Data Science Bootcamp, I learned the basics of data science in six weeks to create this project.

title: Analysis
text:
General
Across the data set, we can a positive correlation between payroll rank and standings. Lookly closely there are notable examples like Leicester City’s 15/16 EPL title.








Where it matters
In European soccer competition, the top four and bottom three standings are important. For the top leagues, a top four place secures Champions League qualification, the most prestigious club soccer tournament; a bottom three place means relegation (demotion to the second division).








Which teams are spending wisely?
To categorize how teams are performing relative to their the payroll rank, I took the difference of standing and payroll rank each year as a measurement. A positive differece means that a team over performed that specific year. The total column represents the sum of the difference in all the years the team appeared in the data set, and rate is the average difference.

title: European Soccer Wages
text:
Model Definition
\[y_i = \beta_0  + \beta_1 x_{1,i} + \epsilon_i\]
with \(y = standing\), \(x_1 =year\), and \(\epsilon_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\).
